doc.title: North American Precious Metals Weekly
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/North American Precious Metals Weekly BofA raised long-term gold and silver prices central bank gold buying outlookNorth_2025-08-31

passages.text: Last week, we increased our long- term (LT) real gold and silver prices by \(+25\%\) and \(+30\%\) , respectively (link to report: Commodity price update: LT gold and silver \(+25\%\) and \(+30\%\) 29- Aug- 25). We include highlights of these commodity price increases hear. We also hypothesize on how much more gold could be purchased by central banks.

We are often asked, for how long central banks could continue purchasing physical gold at the elevated levels of recent years (i.e. \(>1,000\) tonnes (t) annually), and thus continue to exert upward pressure on the gold price. With an insight from the BofA Commodities team that gold holdings at \(30\%\) of total reserve assets would maximize their information ratio (see Global Metals Weekly 25- Mar- 25: Gold plating guns and canons), data from the World Gold Council (WGC), and assuming current spot gold prices, we calculate that the world total of central banks must purchase a little over 11,000 tonnes (t) of gold in order to attain gold holdings of \(30\%\) of total reserves. This is equivalent to around 10 years of buying at recent elevated annual levels of purchasing. If we exclude central banks that already hold at least \(30\%\) of reserve assets in gold, we calculate that the remaining central banks must purchase 24,665t in order to attain gold holdings at \(30\%\) . This is equivalent to over two decades of purchases at recent elevated levels. Conversely, we wonder if this could imply that annual central bank purchase volumes might increase. We view these central bank volume purchase implications as bullish for the gold price.

We raised our LT real gold and silver prices \(+25\%\) and \(+30\%\) to \(\) 2,500\(per ounce (/oz)\) and \(\) 35/oz\$ , respectively. In our view, the conditions that led to the recent strength in the gold price look likely to persist namely: 1) US structural deficit 2) Inflationary pressure from deglobalization 3) Perceived threats to independence of US central bank 4) Global geopolitical tensions & uncertainty. Our average gold price for next 6 years increased \(+6\%\) to \(\) 3,049/oz\(real). Our average silver price increased \(+7.5\%\) to US\) \ \(38/oz\) . On the back of these increases, we raised price objectives (POs) for stocks with exposure. Our near- term gold forecasts were unchanged: 2025E at \(\) 3,356/oz\(, 2026E at\) \ \(3,659 / oz\) . We're bullish gold with a short to medium term target of \(\) 4,000/oz\$

Among our North American Metals & Mining coverage, and on the back of the gold and silver price updates, NAV estimates increased on average by around \(12\%\) , and POs increased on average by around \(11\%\) . The largest PO increase was for Buy- rated Newmont (NEM) with a \(15.5\%\) increase to \(\) 104\(\) (A\) \ \(160\) per share. Our 2025 top North American precious metals pick remains Agnico Eagle Mines (AEM). We like it for its leading track- record on meeting or beating guidance and executing projects, suite of attractive growth projects, significant exploration upside potential within its portfolio, and asset location in top jurisdictions (primarily Canada, Australia, and Finland).

Gold opened last Monday (25- Aug- 25) at \(\) 3,371\(per ounce ( / oz), climbed on Tuesday (26 - Aug - 25) at\) \ \(3,394 / oz\) after the US President Trump's attempt to pressure the Fed leadership, strengthening haven demand on a weaker US dollar, as measured by the DXY Index. Bullion eased on Wednesday (27 - Aug - 25) then steadily rose on Thursday (28 - Aug - 25) at\) \ \(3,417 / oz\) as the market was awaiting Friday's US inflation report to gauge future path for interest rate. Gold spiked on Friday (29 - Aug - 25) as Russia tensions reemerge after Germany and France called for secondary sanctions on countries aiding Russia's war efforts in Ukraine and a US consumption data print proved stubborn inflation. Ultimately ended the week up \(2.3\%\) to \(\) 3,448/oz\(. As for the equities, the\) \ \(\) \mathrm{P} / \mathrm{TSX} \(Global Gold Index, the Philadelphia Gold and Silver Index, and the NYSE Arca Exchange Gold Bugs Index all climbed last week ( + 3.6\%, + 4.1\%, and + 5.3\%, respectively).\)

The World Gold Council (WGC)- published latest world official gold reserves data on August \(5^{\mathrm{th}}\) . Data are compiled from the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS), which tracks central banks' reported purchases and sales along with gold as a percentage of their international reserves. IMF's calculated world total gold holdings are 36,344.5 tonnes, 21.8% share held in gold of total foreign reserves, as calculated by the WGC using end of June LBMA gold price of \(\) 3287.45/\(oz.\) \circ\$

Based on the latest world official gold reserves data, we calculated the implied tonnes of gold for central banks (CB) to purchase in order to reach the most efficient portfolio (as calculated by the BofA Commodities team, using the information ratio (i.e. \(30\%\) in gold), while assuming the current spot gold price of \(\) 3447.95/\(oz.\) \circ\$
Bolivia holds \(96\%\) of its total reserve assets in gold, while Hong Kong holds \(0.05\%\) of its total reserve assets in gold.
Source: World Gold Council, IMF, BofA Global Research. Spot gold price used: \(\) 3447.95/oz.\(BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
Information ratios peak when the share of gold in an average central bank portfolio hits around \(30\%\) .
Source: Bloomberg, IMF, BofA Global Research.

Our \(\) 209\(per share price objective is based on Agnico Eagle trading at 2.75x times our estimated NAV (current net debt position plus a mining asset DCF utilizing a\) 5\%\(WACC). Historically, North American gold producers have traded between 1 and 2 times NAV, with 1.75 - 2.0 times being accorded to the organically growth - oriented gold producers such as AEM.

Risks of this price objective not being attained are commodity price weakness, the inability to secure financing for expansion or development projects, unforeseen operating problems, and political risk in the countries the company operates in. Upside risks are commodity price strength, better- than- forecast operating performance and favorable changes in the political environment in the regions where it operates.

Our price objective for Newmont is \(\) 104\((\mathrm{A}\$ 160) per share, and is based on the stock trading at 2.00x times our estimated net asset value (NAV). We assume a USDAUD exchange rate of 1.54. Our NAV is based on a\) 5\%\(discount rate and a long - term gold price of\) \ \(2,500 / oz\) . Historically, North American precious metal stocks have traded between 1 and 3 times NAV, with a median of 1.50 times over the past three years (2.00 times longer - term), and with unhedged, growth - oriented producers with solid balance sheets occupying the upper end of the range. In the great gold rally of 2011, NEM's multiple peaked at 2.50x.

Upside risks to our price objective are stronger- than- forecast commodity prices, better than expected success at reducing costs and positive regulatory, permitting or operating developments. Downside risks to our price objective for Newmont are the inability to secure financing for expansion or development projects, unforeseen operating problems, political, legal or permitting challenges in the regions in which the company operates, rising capital and operating costs and delays in the development of its growth projects.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0-12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage cluster R2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
